sn_bom_service_definition.description:
Trade Reconciliation and Unmatched Trade Resolution This business activity is the core post-trade process responsible for ensuring that the details of a securities transaction (a trade) executed between two parties—a buyer and a seller—are fully aligned and agreed upon before they can be sent for clearing and settlement.
An unmatched trade (or "out trade") occurs when the trade details recorded by the two counterparties—the buy-side and the sell-side—do not agree. This prevents the transfer of cash and securities and halts the settlement process.
Key Components of the Activity: Data Comparison/Matching: The system or operations team compares key data elements of the trade from both parties' records. These elements include:
Security Identifier (e.g., CUSIP, ISIN)
Quantity (number of shares/bonds)
Price and Total Consideration (money amount)
Trade Date and Settlement Date
Counterparty/Broker details
Discrepancy Identification: If any critical data element differs, the trade is flagged as unmatched or mismatched.
Investigation and Resolution (Break-Clearing): The Operations or Middle Office team immediately investigates the cause of the break. Common causes include:
Manual data entry errors.
Miscommunication between front and back offices.
System failures or connectivity issues.
Allocation errors (for block trades). The team contacts the counterparty to agree on the correct trade terms and input the necessary corrections (known as "fixing the break").
Affirmation: Once both parties' records are updated and agree, the trade is formally affirmed (or "locked-in") and released to the clearing agent (like a Central Counterparty or CCP) for the final settlement process.
The goal of this critical activity is to achieve the highest possible matching rate by the required regulatory deadlines (often by noon on T+1) to minimize operational risk, avoid failed trades, and prevent potential financial penalties or regulatory fines.
